awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: F: Collaborative Research: Taming Big Networks via Embedding
awd_abstract_narration:
In the Internet Age, information entities and objects are interconnected, thereby forming gigantic information networks. Recently, network embedding methods, that create low-dimensional feature representations that preserve the structure of data points in their original space, have been shown to be greatly beneficial for many data mining and machine learning problems over networks. Despite significant research progress, we are still lacking powerful network embedding techniques with theoretical guarantees to effectively deal with massive, heterogeneous, complex and dynamic networks. The PIs aim to develop a new generation of network embedding methods for analyzing massive networks. The research project has the potential to significantly transform graph mining and network analysis. The PIs also plan to develop open course materials and open source software tools that integrate information network analysis and machine learning. 

This project consists of four synergistic research thrusts. First, it develops model-based network embedding to leverage the first-order and second-order proximity of networks. Second, it devises a family of inductive network embedding methods that are able to leverage both linkage information and side information. Third, it develops both local clustering and deep learning based network embedding methods to attack the complex structure of networks such as locality and non-linearity. Fourth, it develops online and stochastic optimization algorithms for different network embedding methods to tackle the fast growth and evolution of modern massive networks. The new methods developed in this project enjoy faster rates of convergence in optimization, lower computational complexities, and statistical learning guarantees. The targeted applications include but are not limited to semantic search and information retrieval in social/information network analysis, expert finding in bibliographical database, and recommendation systems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The Internet Age has led to the creation of vast networks of interconnected information entities and objects. Network embedding methods have emerged as a powerful tool for creating low-dimensional feature representations that preserve the structure of data points in their original space, enabling effective data mining and machine learning over networks. However, despite significant progress, prior network embedding techniques still struggle to deal with the complexities of massive, heterogeneous, complex and dynamic networks. The project has developed a diverse set of powerful network embedding techniques to effectively deal with the above challenges. It significantly transforms graph mining and network analysis in both engineering and scientific domains. 

 

In detail, deep learning based network embedding has been developed to handle the complex structure of networks. A family of inductive network embedding methods has been devised to leverage both linkage information and side information. Online and stochastic optimization algorithms have been developed to tackle the fast growth of modern massive networks. The new methods developed in this project have been shown to enjoy faster rates of convergence in optimization, lower computational complexities, and better statistical learning guarantees. The applications of the developed models and algorithms are numerous, including semantic search and information retrieval in social/information network analysis, recommendation systems, and biological data analytics. The scientific results of the project have been presented in research papers in top conferences in machine learning, data mining, and in invited talks at conferences, workshops and seminars. The PI has developed open course education materials and software tools that integrate information network analysis and machine learning. One graduate student funded by this project has found a tenure-track assistant professor job in academia. 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/03/2023
Modified by: Quanquan Gu
